title: knox-academy-headteacher-urges-pupils-dress-appropriately-decline-standard-uniform
story: Letters have been sent to parents and carers encouraging them to ensure pupils are wearing the appropriate unorm when heading to school.The letter, sent out last Thursday, noted that Covid- mitigations were reducing and attempts were being made to “ to a more ‘normal’ approach to le”.Sue Cook, headteacher at the school, stressed the importance of wearing the school unorm.She said: “Over the past few months, we have noticed a decline in the standard of unorm worn by some of our pupils.“This has included non-black trousers, ripped trousers, crew neck jumpers, leggings sports leggings, jogging bottoms, hooded topsand tops which are short cropped.“None of these items are part of our school unorm and they are not appropriate attire for school.“I would like to stress that the vast majority of young people are dressed appropriately, but the number of young people who are not following unorm expectations has increased.“In the coming weeks and months, we plan to increase our approaches to unorm checks and upholding the expectation of young people wearing a unorm.“We need to know, at a glance, that the young people in the school building are pupils at this school and the school unorm is always a quick way of ensuring this.“A school unorm is something that should be al and not necessarily fashionable.“It also supports our approaches to equity.”

title: overnight-resurfacing-works-a1-thistly-cross-roundabout
story: Transport Scotland’s operating company BEAR Scotland were due to start the works on Tuesday but the work was delayed due to adverse weather conditions.A total of  metres of the westbound section of road on the approach to the Thistly Cross Roundabout is being resurfaced.A spokesperson for BEAR Scotland confirmed the works would take place from .pm to am each day, excluding Saturday and Sunday, until next Friday .He told the Courier: “The reason for the extra nights is that we now only have one team available for this job rather than two.”A signed ersion route will be in place via the A, Countess Road and Summerfield Road through Dunbar, before re-joining the A to Beltonford Roundabout and taking the A to Haddington Junction on the A.The road is closed to ensure the safety of roadworkers and the public during these times.Emergency services will be given access through the works at all times and local access for residents within the closure points will be maintained when it is safe to pass through the work area.

title: new-torness-boss-hopes-find-job-everyone
story: It was confirmed at the end of last year that the nuclear power station would now close two years earlier than planned.About  staff and more than a hundred contractors are employed at the station, which was due to close in March .That timescale has been brought forward two years and Paul Forrest, new station director, stressed that the immediate focus was on continuing generation but that attention would turn to the future of the station within the next couple of years.He said: “These are big institutions and preparation work needs to start, maybe not now but over the next year or so.“We found our first keyway root crack at our inspections there and it was expected.“We found a keyway root cracking at Hunterston in  and some keyway root cracking at Heysham , our sister station, last year. That is within expectations but what that does do is underpins the  date so I think we are more confident now that that will be the date.“One success we got from the Hunterston end-of-generation is we managed to find a job for everybody who wanted to stay here.“The staff levels do go down, there’s no doubt about it, but I’ve just done it.“Hunterston was the first station of the AGR [advanced gas-cooled reactor] fleet to reach the end of generation. I was there, I saw it all, so I’m well positioned to help Torness on their journey. We will be starting our preparations for that in the next couple of years.”Once the station stops generating power, attention will turn to defueling the reactors.That process is expected to take more than three years and will require hundreds of members of staff.Mr Forrest succeeded Tam Al Bishawi, who has moved to EDF’s new Hinkley C power station in Somerset after  years over two spells at the station.However, the -year-old is no stranger to Torness.He has lived in nearby Dunbar for more than  years and has a connection with the power station dating back more than  years.He was involved in the construction and commissioning of the station and has held ious roles, including operations manager and technical and safety manager.He was also plant manager at Torness for nearly two years from December  to September , when he was appointed acting station director at Hunterston B, near West Kilbride in Ayrshire.The “strong supporter” of nuclear power felt that Torness had an important role to play in the years ahead.The father-of-three said: “I will be painting that picture and, as I said, at Hunterston we managed to find a job for everybody who wanted to stay. If I can replicate that, it would be a real success.“That will be one of my main focuses but right now we are generating electricity for about a quarter of Scotland’s electricity needs and that is low-carbon electricity.”

title: controlled-explosion-item-address-west-barns
story: An official police statement to the Courier yesterday said that bomb disposal experts had carried out the controlled explosion on Tuesday - but that information was wrong.Apologising for any inconvience caused, a Police Scotland statement this morning said: "Information initially provided relating to a controlled explosion at the address was inaccurate. No controlled explosion occurred.": Man arrested in West BarnsTodays statement added: "Enquiries are continuing at an address in West Barns. A -year-old man was arrested and released pending further enquiries."For the past week there has been a signicant police, fire and ambulance service presence in West Barns.Police have declined to disclose the nature of the incident but reassured members of the public yesterday that there was no reason to be alarmed nor risk to them and that a police presence would remain in the area as enquiries continued.

title: tower-tranent-pub-back-bang
story: The Tower, formerly The Tower Inn, on Church Street, held a grand opening on Saturday to toast to the doors of the iconic watering hole opening once more.It followed a brief closure of the pub, established in , when it was seemingly sold for residential purposes at the beginning of the year.The building has since been bought back and leased out to remain a community pub to be ran by new business managers Dominic McNeill and Patrick Cairney.The cousins thanked everyone that came out on Saturday and said it had been “a great success”.They added: “We have made the decision to open the pub full time to allow more access to the community.”The new opening hours are: Monday-Wednesday: am-pm Thursday: am-midnight Friday-Saturday: am-am Sunday: am-midnight.A number of events will be announced in the coming weeks, with visitors encouraged to suggest things they would like to see at the pub.Dominic and Patrick added: “Thank you all and please keep the ideas coming, we are listening and are in the middle of implementing some of these ideas.”

title: alpacas-pay-visit-leuchie-house-near-north-berwick
story: Ouzo, Sabre and Mr Darcy made the trip from John Muir Alpacas at Hedderwickhill Farm, near Dunbar, which is home to a herd of  animals.The animals provided entertainment in exchange for carrots.Leuchie House provides care and holiday breaks for people with neurological conditions and the team welcomed the alpacas’ visit for providing their guests with a memorable experience.Victoria Shields, guest engagement manager, said: “The guests really enjoyed the experience and getting to see the alpacas up close. “We are extremely grateful to the team at John Muir Alpacas for bringing them to see us, and we would love to welcome them back again.”

title: dunbar-pipe-band-championships-postponed-third-year
story: Bands from throughout Scotland regularly head to the town for the annual Dunbar Pipe Band Championships.The event, which is held at Hallhill Sports Centre, has been cancelled the last two years due to the coronavirus pandemic.It now looks like this year’s event, scheduled for May , will also not go ahead.Bobby Peters, manager of the sports centre, was disappointed but confident it wouldin .He said: “East Lothian Council, like every other council, has cut back on funding.“Obviously, we lost  and  due to Covid and we knew about the funding and we thought we had somebody  lined up.“Unfortunately, that has not materialised and it looks like we are going to lose it this year.”The event, which features Highland dancing and music by pipe bands from across the country, often attracts more than , people.However, Mr Peters told the Courier that funding of between £, and £, was necessary to hold the event.He said: “It could be this year we have to give it a miss but next year we work harder. In January, we did not even know where we were going to be and were still in the middle of a pandemic nobody knew what was coming.“If it does not happen this year, it will happen next year.”Already, a fundraising page has been set up to try to raise the funding for next year.To make a donation, go to www.gofundme f dunbar-pipe-band-day-

title: plans-gullane-holiday-let-approved
story: Retrospective planning permission was needed for the change of use on Gullane’s Hopetoun Terrace.No changes are to be made to the inside or outside of the flat under Christine Povey’s plans.East Lothian Council noted that no members of the public had objected, while the village’s community council also had no views.The planning department also looked at the duration of the stays.More than halfwere said to be people staying for two or three nights, with the majority being couples aged between  and .Forty-five per cent were said to be for one night, while just five per cent of those using the building were there for between seven and  nights.It was noted the longer stays were often people visiting family members.

title: edinburgh-duathlon-fitness-event-cause-disruption-drivers
story: The Edinburgh Duathlon, which sets off from Gosford House on Sunday at am, is the second duathlon to be held at the county house.The duathlon includes a k run, followed by a k cycle and concluded with another k run.The event, organised by Tough Runner UK, will take place within Gosford House estate and follow a bike course along the coastline.The bicycle route. Image: https:www.plotaroute Due to the event, a lower speed limit of mph on the A between Longniddry and Aberlady from am until pm on Sunday.The section of the A is from  metres north of junction with Wemyss Terrace in Longniddry to the junction with The Pleasance in Aberlady for a distance of .km.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-march-3-7-1997-1972-1922
story: ‘COUNCIL tax rise among lowest in Scotland’ was front page news in the East Lothian Courier on March , .An eight per cent rise in council tax will add £ – just over £ a week – to the annual bill of Band D households in East Lothian, coupled with £. million cuts affecting every area of council spending.Agreeing one of the lowest increases of any Scottish authority yesterday , councillors pledged to protect front-line services such as teachers and home helps and said no public facilities would close.The annual Band D tax bill of £ is coupled with an eight per cent rise in the domestic rate announced by East of Scotland Water which will add an average p per week, giving a combined weekly rate of £. compared with £. last year.East Lothian Council leader, Norman Murray, said: “This has proved the most dficult budget exercise we as councillors have ever had to go through.”  ‘Keeping down vermin’ was a headline in the East Lothian Courier on March , .If council house tenants in Tranent find rats in their homes, Rentokil Laboratories Ltd., will be contacted immediately.This assurance was given by the Clerk of Works, Mr George Gray, at Monday’s meeting of the Town Council.The Council agreed to use the services of Rentokil to get rid of rats and mice.The firm had inspected hedgerows and open spaces in the burgh and found rats and mice in the areas of Seton Court, Fleets Road, Elphinstone Crescent, Blawearie Road, Coalgate Avenue and Sandersons Wynd.In a letter to the Council, Rentokil outlined their pest control plans.They proposed eight inspections and treatments per annum in hedgerows and open ground areas, excluding privately owned and industrial areas. They would carry out treatment against rats and mice in Town Council dwelling houses as the need arose.  AN ALARMING fire ripped through a premises in Dunbar, as reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier on March , .An outbreak of fire, the origin of which is unknown, occurred during the early hours of Friday morning, within the stationary premises owned by Miss Downie.The smell of burning attracted the attention of a lady who resides above the shop, and who promptly gave the alarm.The fire brigade, under Mr Murdoch, was quickly on the spot and had it not been for the expeditious manner in which they tackled the outbreak, the whole tenement might have been destroyed.

title: easter-egg-trail-returns-newhailes-house-gardens
story: The fun trails, forced to be put on hold due to Covid- after Easter , were a fixture of many families’ spring holidays, with about , visitors taking part each year.Newhailes joins  other National Trust for Scotlandproperties to take part in the event from Friday, April , to Monday, April .Visitors can enjoy exploring the grounds of some of Scotland’s most beautul sites, following clues, solving a puzzle and collecting a chocolate reward.Newhailes will also welcome the circus and there will be  hidden golden bunnies around the property, with an additional prize up for grabs for those who find one.Mark Bishop, director of customer and cause for NTS, said: “All of us here at the National Trust for Scotland are so excited to confirm theof our Easter Egg Trails for April.“For our charity, these events are a highlight of our year.”For the full programme of events, see nts.org.uk easter

title: red-letter-days-reveals-adventure-experiences-like-batman---book
story: To celebrate the highly anticipated release of The Batman, the experience days website has brought together some of its exciting adventure experiences to really put hairs on the back of your neck.Save the world and take the wheel of the Batmobile or savour a DC comics-inspired three-course meal.The Batman has no limits and neither should you, here are some of the best experience days to try from Red Letter Days.Superhero Six Mile Driving Thrill. Credit: Red Letter Days Take the drivers seat of the Batmobile because Gotham isnt going to save itself.This unique driving experience is ideal for superhero fans with a need for speed.The Bat-themed car became an iconic symbol for the superhero ever since the original TV series and now fans can put it to the test on a six-mile track.You will receive a full introduction and safety briefing before taking the wheel of the replica car and it is available at  places across the country. The unforgettable experience will cost you £ per person, which is down from £.Put the Batmobile to the test today by visiting the Red Letter Days website.Three Course DC Inspired Lunch at Park Row for Two. Credit: Red Letter Days Enjoy an immersive dining experience at Park Row that will bring the DC Universe to le.Inside a stunning Art Deco building in the heart of Londons Theatreland,  youll find five themed restaurants and bars dedicated to the wonders of DC Comics.Red Letter Days has said that you should "prepare for the unexpected" with this scrummy superhero treat which features everything from levitating drinks to nitro popcorn.Sample three delicious courses from its set menu before taking a tour of the ious themed spaces that Park Row has to offer and enjoying a levitating alcoholic drop each.The exclusive DC-inspired experience is £ for two people and can be purchased now from the Red Letter Days website.                                                                                                              : The Batman review: Glasgow gets its share of the spotlight in Robert Pattinsons Batman debut: Red Letter Days reveals Mothers Day guide with Hot Air Balloon rides and Afternoon Tea                                                                                                                 Three Mile Superhero Driving Thrill. Credit: Red Letter Days Do you want to play Batman but dont want to break the bank  Now you can, with this -mile thrilling drive experience in a replica of the iconic Batmobile.Youll get a full introduction and safety briefing before you fire up the exhaust and play Gothams iconic vigilante.This heart-racing experience is ideal for any Batman fans and can be used at  locations across the UK.It is also been reduced from £ to just £ which makes an absolute bargain. Purchase the Batmobile experience via the Red Letter Days website.Superhero CAPOW Photoshoot Click Connection. Credit: Red Letter Days If youre looking for some superhero fun that the whole family can enjoy, look no further than this Superhero CAPOW photoshoot.Channel your inner superheroes and pose in front of dramatic backdrops like youre in your own Marvel movie.Youll have a range of props from chains and girders to boulders and shields to play with before the photographer uses their superpowers to add in some special effects.Youll get a complimentary ” x ” print as well as £ off wall hangings and albums.It is available at  dferent locations and can be used with up to four people.The superhero photo shoot will cost you £ and can be bought via the Red Letter Days website.Shop the rest of its experience days on the Red Letter Days website.

title: tried-marine-hotel---went
story: It is impossible to stay at The Marine North Berwick and not immediately start picturing yourself in F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic novel The Great Gatsby.More than one person staying informed us that the hotel hadn’t always been that way but, after a dramatic refurbishment last year, the move from bleak to chic has been swt and drastic.The Marine now offers  guest rooms, two unique food and beverage concepts, a spa, pool and fitness centre, and , square feet of flexible meeting and event spaces.Overlooking the th hole of the historic West Links course of North Berwick Golf Club, it boasts scenic views of landmarks including the Firth of Forth and Bass Rock.The panoramic and clear views of sea from the hotel are even betteryou’re lucky enough to catch the East Lothian weather on a good day.But though rainy and bleak during our stay, the views were equally breathtaking. With the lobby offering seating – and a coffee and cocktail service! – and a large welcome desk in the centre of the room, even the reception does its best to cater to the view. It would be easy to spend an entire afternoon in the lobby alone, getting lost in the town’s beauty.Its fair to say, the ‘Grand Old Lady’ is back to her former glory and better than ever...Marine Hotel, North Berwick Set on Cromwell Road, The Marine Hotel North Berwick occupies a prime position just streets away from the town’s charming beach and harbour. Its buttercream stone facade is easy to locate and its large free parking area means carrying luggage to the door is a breeze.For tourists and visitors, the hotel is in a prime position within walking distance of a iety of restaurants, some of which serve the freshest seafood from the harbour, alongside fish and chip takeaways and the well-loved and always popular Alandas Gelato.Upon entry to the hotel foyer, guests will be blown away by the sublime views out of large open windows of the iconic Bass Rock.The revamped Marine Hotel, North Berwick There’s ample free parking, a large restaurant, bar area, spa facilities, free Wi-Fi and more.The lobby at night The design throughout the hotel takes inspiration from Scotland’s world-renowned golf courses and notable figures, with nods to the hotel’s stunning seaside location and surrounding natural wonders.A deep colour palette dominates here: the lobby is a mixed wash of patterned wallpaper and dark emerald window fittings. Seating areas boast a selection of large leather couches and intimate tables of two – both of which offer stunning views of the waters that make North Berwick so popular.The hotel embraces the beauty of the wilderness on its front door, with interiors pulling from the agricultural and architectural history of the area. Local heritage is displayed through framed prints of wildle found on the Bass Rock. The refurbished style is reminiscent of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic The Great Gatsby.The lobby area boasts walls of literature As a perfect location for tourists and local visitors alike, there was a iety of visitors checking in: in the lobby, a mix of young couples and groups of friends, as well as solo visitors with their beloved pooches, socialised.The service was relaxed and without fault. Reception staff were friendly and engaging, recommending restaurants and sight-seeing activities.During checkout, staff members went above and beyond to cater to guests’ needs, with several carrying luggage out to the car park and ensuring checkout was as speedy and calm as possible.Bedside tables reflect the hotels golfing roots The hotel boasts  guest rooms, with many paying homages to iconic golf holes with nightstands designed as golf tee boxes. Guest room carpet complements the nightstands and depicts golf ball and golf club mots within the traditional pattern.Each room is somewhat unique but adheres to the core theme by using pops of deep colour and golfing mots to reflect its sporting heritage.All rooms – Marine King Suite, Marine Deluxe King Seaview, Marine Deluxe King, Marine Classic Double Seaview, Marine Classic Double – come with sizeable bathrooms, high-end toiletries, storage space, iron, safe, coffee and tea, concierge service and a mini-bar.My only criticism is the not-so-subtle patterned wallpaper featured in a number of bedrooms. I would avoid thoseyou are prone to migraines!Haggis Bonbons made a great starter The Marine’s restaurant, The Lawn, offers erse dining options and an extensive all-day menu showcasing the very best of Scottish cuisine. Main courses include options of venison, halibut and duck breast.The quality of the food is a definite selling point I’d recommend the haggis bonbons to start, while the Tweed valley beef with Chimichurri sauce makes for an admirable main course.The only distraction in the dining area was the rather bleak music played throughout dinner. Additionally, I would recommend a late dinner, with the atmosphere of the eatery heating up at around pm.Breakfast is a generous premium buffet served in the restaurant with an additional menu of warm and cooked items the French toast is not to be missed. From my understanding, the pastries on offer at the buffet are made in house and the best I’ve ever eaten.The overall dining experience at The Lawn was high class, most of all due to the eagerness and humour of our server. If you visit The Lawn, with or without a booked stay at The Marine, always ask for Richie!Cocktails created by talented bar staff are the perfect dinner treat Staff are faultless in their presentation, their unorm neat and matching they’re eager to help and accommodate.Marine Hotel North Berwick Without a doubt, the staff are among the most polite and caring I have ever met. A special mention goes to Surajit Dasgupta for his outstanding care and attention throughout the stay. His service alone would justy booking a night’s stay at The Marine.The atmosphere and charm of this hotel is so special that, despite living just a few miles down the road, it felt like a well-needed break from day-to-day le. This does not give you the routine chain hotel vibe, instead a comfortable stay high up on my list of places to . Huge respect to the Marine team, who do a great job here a true example of excellent hospitality!

title: quiet-roads-coming-county
story: East Lothian Council’s Labour-led cabinet is being asked to decide whether to keep the the limits and introduce a new hierarchy of speed restrictions on its roads orto pre-pandemic rules.A new speed limit policy also proposes introducing Quiet Roads in the county which would have signs urging drivers to go slower on lanes which are being used by pedestrians and cyclists.The new policy follows a survey of residents last year which the council says saw six out of  people say they believed the lower speed limits have made it safer for children, with more than half keen to keep them in some,not all, places.However it also found  per cent of residents said drivers ignored the speed limits and more than half said drivers took more risks and were frustrated by the slower speeds, with  per cent having the view that speed limits were not enforced.However  per cent of people questioned said they believed drivers paid more attention to other road users due to reduced speed limits and were less likely to overtake cyclists with a third adding they found it easier to cross roads.: Public urged to have their say on mph zonesThe proposed hierarchy of speeds in East Lothian’s towns would see mph limits on roads on the outskirts of communities, with mph roads described as streets where vehicles are given a higher priority than the “place ”.Speed limits of mph would be introduced in residential streets or those with a high pedestrian or cyclist movement such as town centres or around schools.The policy also covers ways for communities to apply for changes to speed limits in their areas.And it introduces the designation of popular walking areas as Quiet Roads.It says: “Quiet Roads are increasingly being implemented on rural roads across Scotland where there may be high levels of use by pedestrians, cyclists or equestrians.“The presence of vulnerable road users in the carriageway is highlighted to drivers through the use of signage to promote a shared environment.“Where appropriate, East Lothian Council will consider the introduction of Quiet Roads across its network to develop safer movements for vulnerable road users.”

title: mothers-day-gifts-2022-coffee-machines-mugs-gift-sets
story: Mothers Day, which falls on Sunday, March  in , is a whole day dedicated to celebrating mothers, grandmothers and other maternal figures.For those addicted to coffee and caffiene treats, theres plenty of choice - from affordable gt sets to fancy coffee machines.From Mothers Day presents under £ to Nespresso and Lavazzo luxury, were sure youll find the perfect gt right here.Photo of a woman enjoying coffee via Canva Pixabay. Buy via the Anthropologie website here.You can also find a version of the mug in the same design with inidual letters.Whittards of Cha is selling a gorgeous coffee gt set featuring nine of the companys favourite ground coffees for £.With beautully illustrated boxes from all over the world, it is a great gt for people who appreciate trying new coffees and broadening their horizons.Whittards also sells cheaper coffee blends full of flavour for £ - from chocolate truffleand vanillato salted caramel .To make every day feel like Mothers Day, you could buy a three month gt subscription to Coffee Club for £, via Not On The Highstreet.With ground or pre-ground options, Coffee Club sends out two dferent ieties of the freshest coffee from around the world, through your letterbox, every month.For £, Not On The Highstreet is also selling personalised reusable and sustainably made bamboo coffee cups."Perfect for the eco warriors in your le, this gt is unique, elegant andplanet-friendly," creators Global WAKEup said.Even better, % of the organisations profits support The Marine Conservation Society and Plastic Oceans - making it a gt with a conscience.Ambiano Espresso MakerAldi is selling the Ambiano Espresso Maker for those who want a fancy pick me up before the day begins, priced at £.."Brilliant coffee maker for the price," one reviewer said."We love the latte with Aldi coffee, so tasty."Photo shows an espresso machine in action. Once it has finished pouring, the removable drip tray is there ready to be cleaned.Lavazza A Modo Mio JolieWith its sophisticated design, small size and quiet brewing, the Lavazza Jolie is ideal for coffee lovers with red, white and black options.Perfect for hosting, the Jolie will quietly brew a delicious cup of coffee for you and your guests. Perfect for hosting, the Idola satisfies everyone’s needs with a touch interface that lets you choose from four dferent coffee recipes - Espresso, Short Espresso, Long Coffee and Free Dose Coffee – the Idola creates tailor made coffee to enjoy whenever and however you want.The Boost temperature button produces a piping hot espresso with an unmistakable Lavazza aroma, for guaranteed quality every time.This coffee machine is available on the Lavazza online store for £ RRP.Lavazza A Modo Mio, SMEG style coffee machineThe beautul Lavazza A Modo Mio SMEG pairs Lavazza’s espresso expertise with SMEG’s iconic style. The glamourous coffee machine is sure to make a statement in any kitchen.It is available on the Lavazza online store for £ RRP.Lavazza A Modo Mio VoicyThe Voicy is the perfect gt for anyone tech savvy, as it is the first coffee machine to be equipped with built-in Amazon Alexa technology. From a personalised espresso to ristretto, enjoy customised coffee moments via the simple command: “Alexa, make me a coffee”.This coffee machine is available on the Lavazza online store for £ RRP.

title: canary-islands-scrap-covid-rules---best-holidays-jet2-thomas-cook
story: Whether youre looking for a relaxing romantic escape with a partner, an active trip with friends or a fun budget break for the whole family, weve got you covered.We have rounded up the travel rules for jetting off to Spain as we head into the summer season to take the stress out of your trip.Not to mention, we have also included some of the best holiday deals from some of the biggest names including Thomas Cook, Jet and Love Holidays.A beach on the Canary Islands. Credit: Canva Until recently only full vaccinated holidaymakers were allowed into the country but now unvaccinated travellers who have recently recovered from the virus are allowed to enter.There have also been changes to the rules for unvaccinated - years old who can now fly to Spain with a negative PCR test resultthey are accompanied by vaccinated adults.You will also still need your pre-travel forms and QR codes at border control for the moment.Dont forget that you need to have had your most recent vaccine within a -month course to be considered doubled jabbed.                                                                                                            : Expedias top travel hacks on flights and accommodation - See the best tips: Tripadvisor reveals best destinations for  - See the full list of winners                                                                                                            Safe Spain, the countrys official travel website says: "From February , , in order to travel to Spain with a vaccination certicate, the certicate must have been issued by the competent authorities of the country of origin at least  days after the date of administration of the last dose of the full course of vaccination, as long as the final dose of that course of vaccination was no more than  days ago."Spain is currently operating on a traffic light system that includes the Canary Islands.Tenere is currently in level three, while Gran Canaria is in level four meaning that there are still capacity limits in some bars and nightclubs.Spain looks set to lt all of its restrictions, including facemasks, by June but we dont have a confirmed date yet.For more information, visit the Safe Spain website for details.Plane in the sky. Credit: Canva TenereFor an adult break away from the kids, The Coral Ocean View in Tenere is an award-winning hotel and Tripadvisors Travellers choice for .The all-inclusive package is available for £ per person with no shortage of facilities on offer. Book your stay via the Jet website.LanzaroteIf youve been lusting over a trip to Lanzarote, look no further than the H Rubicon Palace on the Playa Blanca. The stunning accommodation hosts eight outdoor pools, the thalasso spa and rooms making it the perfect place to unwind. Take in the tranquil ocean views for £ per person and book your bargain break via the Jet  website now.FuerteventuraGet your passports ready for this fantastic deal to Fuerteventura in Thomas Cooks flight and hotel package.Lounge at the pool for a stress-free seven-night stay at the Globales Costa Tropical and only pay £ to secure it today.Check the availability and book your holiday for only £ per person via the Thomas Cook website.A traveller with their bag, passport and ticket. Credit: Canva Gran CanariaTreat yourself to a seven-night bed and breakfast escape as you unwind at Gran Canaria Princess on the Playa del Ingles. Lounge about at the two outdoor swimming pools, the sun terrace or four whirlpools.Secure the fantastic flight and holiday package for just £ now and pay £ per person via the Thomas Cook website. La PalmaIf you fancy jetting off to La Palma this summer, you need to see this flight and hotel package deal from Love Holidays. This adult-only La Palma  Teneguia Princess Vital  Fitness hotel can be found just across from the beach and a short walk away from the centre of Santa Cruz De La Palma.Book the combo flight and hotel package for £ per person with Love Holidays price march guarantee.Sort out your summer holiday in the Canaries now via the Love Holidays website.TenereYou deserve a holiday soaking in the sun and recharge your batteries so why not treat yourself to a trip to Tenere

title: aldi-lidl-middle-aisles-sunday-march-6
